{
  "article_text": [
    "riemannian symmetric spaces are characterized by the existence of special isometries called _ central involutions _ : for each point @xmath2 of such a space @xmath3 , there exists an involution @xmath4 such that @xmath2 is an isolated fixed point of @xmath5 and @xmath6 .",
    "the group of displacements of a riemannian symmetric space @xmath3 is the subgroup of the isometry group isom(@xmath3 ) which is generated by pairwise products of central involutions .",
    "it is a classical fact that for connected symmetric spaces , it coincides with the identity component @xmath7 ( see for example proposition  iv-1.4 of @xcite ) .",
    "this means that every isometry in the identity component is a product of a finite ( even ) number of central involutions .",
    "it is then a natural question to ask , given a symmetric space @xmath3 , what the central involution length of @xmath7 is , i.e. the smallest @xmath8 ( if any ) such that any element of @xmath7 is a product of at most @xmath1 central involutions .",
    "one can also relax the question to more general involutions , which is also of geometric interest as it allows for example to consider reflections , which have fixed - point loci of maximal ( rather than minimal ) dimension .",
    "basmajian and maskit investigated in @xcite the involution length of @xmath9 when @xmath3 is a symmetric space of constant ( sectional ) curvature , i.e. one of the model spaces @xmath10 , @xmath11 or @xmath12 .",
    "they found that , allowing orientation - reversing involutions the involution length is always 2 , whereas if one restricts to orientation - preserving involutions ( i.e. involutions in the identity component @xmath7 ) it is 2 or 3 , depending explicitly on the space and the congruence class of @xmath1 mod .",
    "they deduce from these facts that every element of @xmath7 is a commutator , i.e. the commutator length of @xmath7 is 1 .",
    "this follows from the remark that every square of a triple product of involutions is a commutator",
    ". indeed , for any triple of involutions @xmath13 , we have    @xmath14.\\ ] ]    in this paper we study the analogous question in @xmath9 when @xmath3 is complex hyperbolic space @xmath15 , the model complex symmetric space of constant negative holomorphic sectional curvature . here",
    "@xmath9 has 2 connected components , one consisting of all holomorphic isometries ( the identity component , isomorphic to @xmath16 ) and the other consisting of all antiholomorphic isometries .",
    "it is well known that any element of @xmath16 is a product of 2 antiholomorphic involutions ( usually called _ real reflections _ ) ;",
    "this was originally observed by falbel and zocca in @xcite when @xmath17 then for all values of @xmath1 by choi in @xcite ( see also @xcite , and @xcite for the elliptic case , corresponding to @xmath18 ) .",
    "however , only special elements of @xmath16 are products of two holomorphic involutions ( see lemma  [ doubleproducts ] in the case of pu(2,1 ) ) .",
    "the involution length of @xmath16 is thus at least 3 ( for @xmath19 ) .",
    "our main result is the following :    [ main ] the involution length of @xmath20 is 4 .",
    "( we also show the analogous statements where `` involution '' is replaced by `` central involution '' , or by `` complex reflection of order 2 '' . ) more specifically , we show that all loxodromic and parabolic isometries in @xmath20 are triple products of involutions , whereas some elliptic conjugacy classes are not .",
    "more precisely , we give in proposition [ prop - ell - triple ] and corollary [ coro - ell - triple ] a precise description of those regular elliptic elements that are not products of three involutions .",
    "this description is made in terms of the _ angle pair _ of an elliptic isometry .",
    "elliptic isometries preserve two orthogonal complex lines on which they act by rotation ; the angle pair is the pair formed by these two rotation angles ( see section [ section - ell - classes ] ) .",
    "the angle pair determines the conjugacy class of an elliptic element .",
    "it should be noted that there is a slight subtlety here .",
    "loxodromic conjugacy classes in pu(2,1 ) are determined unambiguously by the trace of any lift to su(2,1 ) .",
    "this is not the case for elliptic isometries : for a given value of the trace , there are generically three possible angle pairs , which correspond to the various possible relative positions of eigenvectors and the light - cone in @xmath21 ( see section [ section - ell - classes ] ) . in particular , one can show that any complex number can be realized as the trace of a triple product of involutions though not all isometries are products of three involutions .",
    "our method is based on the use of the product map on the product of two semisimple conjugacy classes ( see e.g. @xcite ) .",
    "let @xmath22 and @xmath23 be two conjugacy classes .",
    "the product map on @xmath24 is defined by @xmath25 ,   \\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where @xmath26 is the space of conjugacy classes of pu(2,1 ) ( see section [ space - conj ] ) and @xmath27 $ ] denotes the conjugacy class of an element .",
    "we review the main properties of this map in section [ section - product - map ] .",
    "the image by @xmath28 of reducible pairs @xmath29 form the so - called _",
    "reducible walls _ that divide @xmath26 into _",
    "chambers_. the crucial fact is that when @xmath22 and @xmath23 are semisimple classes , these chambers are either full or empty , i.e. @xmath30 is a union of chamber closures ( see sections [ section - closed ] , [ section - open ] ) . in our case",
    "we consider this map when @xmath22 is the conjugacy class of a product of two involutions and @xmath23 is the conjugacy class of an involution . applying this method",
    "we are able to determine which elliptic and loxodromic conjugacy classes are triple products of involutions .",
    "we have to deal with parabolic conjugacy classes separately as they are nt semisimple and can not be separated from conjugacy classes of complex reflections . to prove that the involution length of pu(2,1 ) is 4 , we show that the map @xmath28 becomes surjective when both @xmath22 and @xmath23 are conjugacy classes of products of two involutions .",
    "we also obtain as a byproduct of these results that @xmath20 has commutator length 1 ( theorem  [ comm ] ) , but slightly more indirectly than in @xcite .",
    "indeed , we show that even though not every element of @xmath20 is a triple product of involutions , it is the square of a triple product of involutions and conclude using .    in higher dimensions ,",
    "i.e. in @xmath16 with @xmath0 , the involution length will be at least 3 , for the same reason as above ( pairwise products of involutions have special properties ) .",
    "however the finer methods that we use in this work to improve the lower bound to 4 ( so , prove that not every element is a product of 3 involutions ) , and provide an upper bound of 4 ( so , prove that every element is a product of 4 involutions ) do not extend easily to higher dimensions , as they rely on a detailed understanding the chamber structure in the space of elliptic conjugacy classes in @xmath20 ( see section [ section - product - map ] for more details ) , which gets significantly more complicated in higher dimensions .",
    "djokovic and malzan proved in @xcite that the length of @xmath31 with respect to complex reflections of order 2 is @xmath32 , and in @xcite that the corresponding length in @xmath33 ( with @xmath34 ) is @xmath35 or @xmath36 ( depending on the parity of @xmath37 ) . by combining our results for @xmath17 with results of @xcite ( namely their bound on the involution length of @xmath31 ) we obtain the following result ( theorem  [ invollengthn ] ) :    [ invollengthn ] for all @xmath19 , the involution length of pu(@xmath1,1 ) is at most 8 .    the paper is organized as follows . in section",
    "[ section - classical ] , we present some classical facts on products of isometries in the poincar disk for later reference .",
    "section  [ section - pu21 ] is devoted to the description of conjugacy classes in pu(2,1 ) . in section [ section - product - map ] ,",
    "we introduce the product map and describe the general strategy to determine its image .",
    "we then apply this strategy in sections  [ section - triple - loxo ] and [ section - reg - ell - product ] , to determine which loxodromic and regular elliptic isometries are products of three involutions .",
    "we deal with parabolic conjugacy classes in section [ section - parab - triple ] .",
    "finally , in section [ section - consequences ] , we apply these results to study the involution length and commutator length .",
    "* acknowledgements : * part of this research took place during visits to grenoble university ,",
    "arizona state university and icerm ; we would like to thank these institutions for their hospitality . the authors acknowledge support from the nsf ( grant dms 1249147 and grants dms 1107452 , 1107263 , 1107367 `` rnms : geometric structures and representation varieties '' - the gear network ) , the simons foundation ( collaboration grant for mathematicians 318124 ) and the anr project sgt .",
    "the authors would like to thank jon mccammond , as well as martin deraux and elisha falbel for helpful conversations .",
    "[ length - psl2r ] ( 1 ) every element of psl(2,@xmath38 ) is a product of two reflections .",
    "+ ( 2 ) every antiholomorphic isometry of the poincar disk is a product of three reflections .",
    "+ ( 3 ) every element of psl(2,@xmath38 ) is a product of at most three half - turns .",
    "_ proof_. the first part of proposition [ length - psl2r ] is classical ( see for instance sections 7.32 to 7.35 ) of @xcite ) .",
    "the second part follows , as any antiholomorphic isometry of the poincar disk is the product of an element of psl(2,@xmath38 ) and a reflection ( e.g. @xmath39 ) . for the third part ,",
    "we proceed by case by case analysis .",
    "+ ( a ) any hyperbolic element @xmath40 is a product of two half turns with fixed points a distance @xmath41 apart on its invariant axis , where @xmath42 is the translation length of @xmath40 . + ( b ) to see that elliptic elements are products of three half - turns , consider a triangle @xmath43 in the poincar disk , with internal angles @xmath44 , @xmath45 . let @xmath46 be the half - turn about the midpoint of the edge @xmath47 $ ] of @xmath48 , where indices are taken modulo @xmath49 ( see figure [ elliptic-3-half - turns ] )",
    ". then @xmath50 is elliptic ( it fixes @xmath51 ) , and it is a simple exercice in plane hyperbolic geometry to see that its rotation angle is @xmath52 . changing @xmath50 to its inverse @xmath53 , we see that any non - zero rotation angle in @xmath54 can be obtained this way .",
    "elliptic elements with angle @xmath55 are obtained in the case where @xmath56 .",
    "+ ( c ) for parabolic elements , consider an ideal triangle @xmath43 in the poincar disk , and let @xmath46 be the half - turn fixing the orthogonal projection of @xmath57 onto the opposite edge ( see figure [ parabolic-3-half - turns ] ) .",
    "the product @xmath50 fixes @xmath51 , and is parabolic .",
    "this can be seen for instance by considering the orbit of a horosphere based at @xmath51 ( one can also argue that the group by @xmath58 is conjugate to an index 3 subgroup of the modular group psl(2,@xmath59 ) , and that @xmath50 corresponds to the cube of the parabolic element @xmath60 under this conjugation ) .",
    "@xmath61    for later use , we describe the possible conjugacy classes for the product of two isometries of the poincar disk lying in certain prescribed conjugacy classes .",
    "[ prop - invol - hyp - disc][prop - geod - sym - hyper ] ( 1 ) let @xmath62 be a hyperbolic conjugacy class in psl(2,@xmath38 ) .",
    "( a ) the product of an element @xmath63 and a half - turn can belong to any nontrivial conjugacy class .",
    "in particular , it can be elliptic with arbitrary rotation angle .",
    "( b ) the product of an element @xmath63 and a reflection is a glide reflection with arbitrary translation length .",
    "+ ( 2 ) let @xmath22 and @xmath23 be two elliptic conjugacy classes in psl(2,@xmath38 ) , corresponding to rotation angles @xmath64 and @xmath65 ( with @xmath66 ) . if @xmath67 and @xmath68 are such that @xmath69 is elliptic , then the rotation angle of @xmath69 can take any value in @xmath70 ( resp .",
    "$ ] ) if @xmath72 ( resp .",
    "@xmath73 ) .",
    "+ ( 3 ) let @xmath22 and @xmath23 be two hyperbolic conjugacy classes in psl(2,@xmath38 ) , corresponding to translation lengths @xmath74 and @xmath75 . then every elliptic isometry is a product @xmath76 with @xmath77 and @xmath78 .    _ proof_. ( 1a ) let @xmath63 ( with translation length denoted @xmath42 ) , and let @xmath79 be a half - turn .",
    "let @xmath80 be the geodesic orthogonal to the axis of @xmath40 through the fixed point of @xmath79 , and @xmath81 the reflection about @xmath80 ( see figure [ saccheri ] ) .",
    "let @xmath82 be the unique reflection such that @xmath83 ; it fixes pointwise a geodesic @xmath84 which is at distance @xmath41 from @xmath80 .",
    "the half - turn @xmath79 is the product of @xmath81 and the reflection @xmath85 about the geodesic @xmath86 orthogonal to @xmath80 through @xmath2 .",
    "the product @xmath87 is equal to @xmath88 . as in figure",
    "[ saccheri ] , we see that when @xmath2 moves away from the axis of @xmath40 , the relative position of @xmath84 and @xmath86 varies continuously from orthogonal ( when @xmath2 is on the axis of @xmath40 ) to disjoint with arbitrarily large distance ( when @xmath2 goes to infinity along @xmath80 ) .",
    "we thus obtain elliptic classes with any rotation angle @xmath89 ( when @xmath84 and @xmath86 intersect ) , a parabolic class ( when @xmath84 and @xmath86 are asymptotic ) , and any hyperbolic class ( when @xmath84 and @xmath86 are ultra - parallel ) .",
    "the other elliptic classes are obtained by applying the reflection about the axis of @xmath40 , which reverses orientation .",
    "+ ( 1b ) let @xmath63 , with translation length denoted @xmath42 .",
    "write @xmath83 , where @xmath81 and @xmath82 are reflections about geodesics @xmath80 and @xmath84 orthogonal to the axis of @xmath40 , and a distance @xmath41 apart .",
    "now consider a geodesic @xmath90 , orthogonal to @xmath80 and @xmath91 the reflection about it .",
    "the product @xmath92 is the half - turn about the point @xmath93 .",
    "therefore @xmath94 is the product of a reflection and a half - turn , which is a glide reflection ( as @xmath2 is not fixed by @xmath82 ) . as @xmath90 moves away from the axis of @xmath40 , the translation length @xmath95 of @xmath94 can take any positive value ( see figure [ fig - geod - sym - hyper ] ) .",
    "+ ( 2 ) let @xmath86 be the geodesic connecting the fixed points of @xmath96 and @xmath97 , and @xmath85 the associated reflection .",
    "decompose the two elliptics as products @xmath98 and @xmath99 , where @xmath81 and @xmath82 are reflections about geodesics through the fixed points of @xmath96 and @xmath97 .",
    "the geodesics @xmath80 and @xmath84 intersect @xmath86 with angles @xmath100 and @xmath101 , as indicated on figure [ fig - prod - ell - disc ] .",
    "the product @xmath102 is elliptic if and only if @xmath80 and @xmath84 intersect inside the disk .",
    "the result follows by studying the possible angles of the triangle bounded by @xmath80 , @xmath84 and @xmath86 when the distance between the fixed points of @xmath96 and @xmath97 varies .",
    "+ ( 3 ) the argument is about the same as for the previous item .",

    "s convenience we include a brief summary of key definitions and facts .",
    "our main result concerns the case of dimension @xmath17 , but the general setup is identical for higher dimensions so we state it for all @xmath109 .    [ [ distance - function ] ] distance function : + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +    consider @xmath110 , the vector space @xmath111 endowed with a hermitian form @xmath112 of signature @xmath113 . let @xmath114 .",
    "let @xmath115 denote projectivization .",
    "define @xmath116 to be @xmath117 , endowed with the distance @xmath118 ( bergman metric ) given by :    @xmath119    different choices of hermitian forms of signature @xmath113 give rise to different models of @xmath120 .",
    "the two most standard choices are the following .",
    "first , when the hermitian form is given by @xmath121 , the image of @xmath122 under projectivization is the unit ball of @xmath123 , seen in the affine chart @xmath124 of @xmath125 .",
    "this model is referred to as the _ ball model _ of @xmath120 . secondly , when @xmath126 , we obtain the so - called _ siegel model _ of @xmath120 , which generalizes the poincar upper half - plane .    [ [ isometries ] ] isometries : + + + + + + + + + + +    from it is clear that @xmath16 acts by isometries on @xmath116 , where @xmath127 denotes the subgroup of @xmath128 preserving @xmath129 , and @xmath130 its image in @xmath131 .",
    "in fact , pu(@xmath1,1 ) is the group of holomorphic isometries of @xmath116 , and the full group of isometries is @xmath132 , where the @xmath133 factor corresponds to a real reflection ( see below ) .",
    "holomorphic isometries of @xmath120 can be of three types , depending on the number and location of their fixed points .",
    "namely , @xmath134 is :    * _ elliptic _ if it has a fixed point in @xmath116 * _ parabolic _ if it has ( no fixed point in @xmath116 and ) exactly one fixed point in @xmath135 * _ loxodromic _ : if it has ( no fixed point in @xmath116 and ) exactly two fixed points in @xmath135    [ [ totally - geodesic - subspaces ] ] totally geodesic subspaces : + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + + +    a _ complex k - plane _ is a projective @xmath136-dimensional subspace of @xmath125 intersecting @xmath137 non - trivially ( so , it is an isometrically embedded copy of @xmath138 ) .",
    "complex 1-planes are usually called _",
    "complex lines_. if @xmath139 is a complex @xmath140-plane , any @xmath141 orthogonal to @xmath142 is called a _ polar vector _ of @xmath143 .",
    "such a vector satisfies @xmath144 , and we will usually normalize @xmath145 so that @xmath146 .    a _ real k - plane _ is the projective image of a totally real @xmath147-subspace @xmath148 of @xmath110 , i. e. a @xmath147-dimensional real vector subspace such that @xmath149 for all @xmath150 .",
    "we will usually call real 2-planes simply real planes , or @xmath38-planes .",
    "every real @xmath1-plane in @xmath116 is the fixed - point set of an antiholomorphic isometry of order 2 called a _ real reflection _ or @xmath38-reflection .",
    "the prototype of such an isometry is the map given in affine coordinates by @xmath151 ( this is an isometry provided that the hermitian form has real coefficients ) .    in @xmath152 , the relative position of complex lines",
    "can be determined using using the following lemma .",

    "if @xmath153 and @xmath154 have opposite types , say @xmath153 has positive type and @xmath154 negative type , then @xmath163 and @xmath164 , where @xmath165 .",
    "in particular @xmath166 if and only if @xmath167 belongs to @xmath168 .",
    "if @xmath153 and @xmath154 both have positive type , then : 1 .",
    "@xmath168 and @xmath169 are ultraparallel @xmath170 ; in that case @xmath161 , where @xmath171 , 2 .   @xmath168 and @xmath169 intersect inside @xmath172 ; in that case @xmath173 , where @xmath174 is the angle between @xmath168 and @xmath169 , 3 .",
    "@xmath168 and @xmath169 are asymptotic if and only if @xmath175 .",
    "_ proof_. the first item comes from the distance between two points in @xmath152 , which is given by .",
    "the third one is a reformulation of section 3.3.2 of @xcite . to prove the second one",
    ", we note that if @xmath153 is polar to @xmath168 , then the orthogonal projection of @xmath167 on @xmath168 is given by the vector @xmath176 the distance between @xmath177 and @xmath169 is then obtained by applying to @xmath178 and @xmath154 , and this gives the result .",
    "@xmath61    [ rem - asymptotic - lines ]",
    "let @xmath153 and @xmath154 be two positive type vectors polar to two complex lines @xmath168 and @xmath169",
    ". the two vectors are linearly independant if and only if @xmath168 and @xmath169 are disinct .",
    "when this is the case there exists a ( unique up to scalar multiples ) vector @xmath179 which is orthogonal to both @xmath153 and @xmath154 .",
    "this vector can be taken to be @xmath180 ( where @xmath181 denotes the hermitian cross product , as defined in section 2.2.7 . of @xcite ) .",
    "it is sometimes useful to note that if @xmath168 and @xmath169 are distinct , they are asymptotic if and only if the family @xmath182 is linearly dependent .",
    "this can be seen easily , for instance by considering the gram matrix of this family for @xmath183 .",
    "we provide a few details about the 2-dimensional siegel model , as we will use it a lot when working with parabolic isometries .",
    "it is the one associated to the hermitian form given by @xmath184 the complex hyperbolic plane corresponds to the domain given by @xmath185 for @xmath186 ( seen as the affine chart @xmath187 of @xmath188 ) .",
    "any point in @xmath152 lifts to a unique vector in @xmath189 of the form @xmath190 the triple @xmath191 is called _ horospherical coordinates _ for @xmath192 .",
    "in these coordinates , the boundary of @xmath152 is formed by those points for which @xmath193 , that is the projections of the vectors @xmath194 , together with the point at infinity , which is the projection of @xmath195 . in turn , the boundary of @xmath196 is the one point compactification of the 3-dimensional heisenberg group @xmath197 , with group law @xmath198\\cdot[w , s]=[z+w , t+s+2\\im(z\\overline{w})].\\ ] ] we will see below that left heisenberg multiplication corresponds to the action of a unipotent parabolic isometry fixing the point at infinity ( see section [ section - para - classes ] ) .",
    "these parabolics preserve each level set of @xmath199 ( which are in fact the horospheres centred at @xmath200 ) .",
    "we often call @xmath201 $ ] the heisenberg coordinates of the point in the boundary of @xmath152 given by @xmath194 .",
    "note that @xmath202 ; in particular , if @xmath203 , then the vector @xmath204 is polar to a complex line .",
    "in fact , a complex line is either polar to a vector @xmath204 for some @xmath203 ( if it does not contain @xmath200 ) , or polar to a vector of the form @xmath205 ( if it does ) .",
    "the latter vector is polar to the complex line connecting @xmath200 to the boundary point with heisenberg coordinates @xmath206 $ ] .",
    "we denote by @xmath207 , @xmath208 and @xmath209 the spaces of loxodromic , parabolic and elliptic conjugacy classes in pu(2,1 ) .",
    "we will say an eigenvalue of a transformation @xmath210 has _ positive type _",
    "( resp . _ null type _ , resp .",
    "_ negative type _ ) if it corresponds to a positive ( resp .",
    "null , resp .",
    "negative ) type eigenvector .      in the siegel model ,",
    "any loxodromic isometry is conjugate to one given by the diagonal matrix @xmath211 for some @xmath212 ( the attracting eigenvalue of @xmath213 ) .",
    "the parameter @xmath214 is uniquely defined up to multiplication by a cube root of @xmath215 ( this corresponds to the three lifts to su(2,1 ) of an element in pu(2,1 ) ) .",
    "writing @xmath216 with @xmath217 , we see that @xmath207 is homeomorphic to the cylinder @xmath218 , where @xmath219 is the interval @xmath220 $ ] with endpoints identified .",
    "the parameter @xmath174 is the _ rotation angle _ of @xmath213 ; the translation length of @xmath213 is given by @xmath221 .",
    "note that the unit modulus eigenvalue of a loxodromic element does not determine its conjugacy class , but it determines its rotation angle , in particular the vertical line of the cylinder @xmath207 to which it belongs .",
    "we will call _ hyperbolic _ any loxodromic isometry with angle @xmath222 ( that is , conjugate to @xmath223 for some @xmath224 ) . similarly , we will call _",
    "half - turn loxodromics _ those with rotation angle @xmath225 ( conjugate to @xmath226 , with @xmath224 ) .",
    "the axis of a loxodromic isometry @xmath143 is contained in an @xmath219-family @xmath227 of real planes on which @xmath143 acts by rotation : @xmath228 , where @xmath174 is the rotation angle of @xmath143 . in particular ,",
    "hyperbolic ( resp half - turn loxodromic ) isometries preserve each real plane containing their axis and act on it as a hyperbolic isometry ( resp . glide reflection ) .",
    "we will denote by @xmath229 the space of hyperbolic conjugacy classes .",
    "vertical lines in @xmath207 are those with fixed value of @xmath174 .",
    "hyperbolic and half - turn loxodromic classes form the vertical lines @xmath222 and @xmath225 . using , it is easy to see that a loxodromic map is hyperbolic ( resp .",
    "half - turn loxodromic ) if and only if it has a lift to su(2,1 ) with real trace larger than @xmath49 ( resp .",
    "less than @xmath230 ) .",
    "parabolic isometries are those whose lifts to su(2,1 ) are non - diagonalizable .",
    "a parabolic isometry is called _ unipotent _ if it has a unipotent lift to su(2,1 ) ; otherwise , it is called _ screw - parabolic _ ( or _ ellipto - parabolic _ , see e.g. @xcite or @xcite ) .",
    "a unipotent parabolic isometry is called either _ 2-step _ or _",
    "3-step _ , according to whether the minimal polynomial of its unipotent lift is @xmath231 or @xmath232 ( see section 3.4 of @xcite ) . in the first case ( also called _ vertical heisenberg translation",
    "_ the unipotent lift is conjugate to one of the following matrices : @xmath233 in the second case , ( also called _ horizontal heisenberg translation _ ) , the unipotent lift is conjugate to @xmath234 the terms horizontal and vertical heisenberg translation refer to the fact that the boundary of complex hyperbolic space can be identified with the heisenberg group , and unipotent parabolics acts on the boundary as left heisenberg translations .",
    "we refer the reader to chapter 4 of @xcite , or to section 2.3 of @xcite .",
    "screw - parabolic isometries have a lift conjugate to a matrix of the form @xmath235 note the latter matrix does not have determinant 1 .",
    "the parameter @xmath174 is called the _ rotation angle _ of the screw - parabolic , and @xmath236 its translation length .",
    "screw - parabolic isometries preserve a complex line , on which they act as a usual parabolic isometry of the poincar disk , and they rotate through an angle @xmath174 around this line . in particular , we will call _ half - turn parabolic maps _ those screw parabolic maps with rotation angle @xmath55 .",
    "parabolic isometries having a lift to su(2,1 ) with real trace are either unipotent or half - turn parabolic .",
    "screw parabolics and 2-step unipotent parabolic have a stable complex line ( in and , it is the one polar to the second vector of the canonical basis of @xmath189 ) . on the other hand , they preserve no real plane . likewise , 3-step unipotent parabolics preserve a real plane ( in the case of , it is the projection of @xmath237 to @xmath152 ) , but no complex line .    as explained in section [ 2-siegel ] , the boundary of @xmath152",
    "can be identified to the one point compactification of the heisenberg group .",
    "all unipotent isometries can be written under the form @xmath238}=\\begin{bmatrix } 1 & -\\overline{z}\\sqrt{2 } & -|z|^2+it\\\\ 0 & 1 & z\\sqrt{2}\\\\ 0 & 0 & 1\\end{bmatrix}\\mbox { where } z\\in{\\mathbb{c}}\\mbox { and } t\\in{\\mathbb{r}}.\\ ] ] it is a direct verification to see that these matrices respect the group multiplication law given in : @xmath239}\\cdot t_{[w , s]}=t_{[z , t]\\cdot[w , s]}\\ ] ] for that reason , unipotent parabolics are often called _",
    "heisenberg translations_. in particular , the representatives of the unipotent conjugacy classes given in and are @xmath240}$ ] and @xmath241}$ ] .      an elliptic isometry @xmath242 is called _ regular _ if any of its matrix representatives @xmath243 has distinct eigenvalues .",
    "the eigenvalues of a matrix @xmath243 representing an elliptic isometry @xmath242 have modulus one .",
    "exactly one of these eigenvalues has eigenvectors in @xmath122 ( projecting to a fixed point of @xmath242 in @xmath116 ) , and such an eigenvalue will be called _ of negative type_. regular elliptic isometries have an isolated fixed point in @xmath116 .",
    "a non regular elliptic isometry is called _",
    "special_. among the special elliptic isometries are the following two types ( which exhaust all special elliptic types when @xmath17 ) :    1 .",
    "a _ complex reflection _ is an elliptic isometry @xmath244 whose fixed - point set is a complex @xmath140-plane . in other words ,",
    "any lift of such an isometry to u(n,1 ) has a negative type eigenvalue of multiplicity @xmath1 .",
    "complex reflection in a point _ is an elliptic isometry whose lifts have a simple eigenvalue of negative type and another eigenvalue of multiplicity @xmath1 . in other words ,",
    "such an isometry is conjugate to @xmath245 ( for some @xmath246 ) , where @xmath18 is the stabilizer of the origin in the ball model .",
    "complex reflections in a point of order 2 are also called _ central involutions _ ; these are the symmetries that give @xmath116 the structure of a symmetric space .    in the ball model of @xmath152 , any lift of an elliptic isometry @xmath242 is conjugate to a diagonal matrix of the form : @xmath247 here",
    "the negative type eigenvalue is @xmath248 .",
    "the two positive eigendirections correspond to a pair of ( orthogonal ) stable complex lines in @xmath152 , and the negative one to a fixed point inside @xmath152 .",
    "projectively , the isometry @xmath242 acts on its stable lines as rotations , through angles @xmath249 and @xmath250 respectively .",
    "the conjugacy class of an elliptic isometry is determined by this ( unordered ) pair of angles .",
    "in particular , the eigenvalue spectrum of a lift to su(2,1 ) of an elliptic isometry does not determine it conjugacy class there are generically three possible angle pairs for a given triple of eigenvalues .",
    "conversely , an elliptic conjugacy class with angle pair @xmath251 is represented by the following matrix in su(2,1 ) : @xmath252 we denote by @xmath209 the space of elliptic conjugacy classes in pu(2,1 ) . from the above discussion",
    ", we may identify @xmath209 with the quotient of @xmath253 under the relation @xmath254 , in other words with : @xmath255 with identifications @xmath256 for all @xmath174 ; see figure [ elliptics ] ) .",
    "an elliptic isometry is said to be _ real elliptic with angle @xmath174 _ if its angle pair is of the form @xmath257 with @xmath258 $ ] .",
    "one of the lifts to su(2,1 ) of such an isometry has eigenvalues @xmath259 ( with @xmath215 of negative type ) , and trace@xmath260 .",
    "the two conditions of having a lift with real trace and negative type eigenvalue equal to @xmath215 characterize real elliptics among elliptics .",
    "moreover , that lift is conjugate to an element of @xmath261 ; in particular , real elliptics preserve a real plane , on which they act by rotation through angle @xmath174 .",
    "[ invols ] there are two conjugacy classes of involutions in pu(2,1 ) :    1 .",
    "_ central involutions _ ( or complex relections in a point of order 2 ) are the isometries conjugate to @xmath262 in the ball model .",
    "they have angle pair @xmath263 , i.e. are real elliptics with angle @xmath55 .",
    "central involutions have an isolated fixed point in @xmath152 , and preserve every complex line through that fixed point , acting on it as a half - turn .",
    "_ complex symmetries _ ( or complex reflections of order 2 ) are the isometries conjugate to @xmath264 in the ball model .",
    "they have angle pair @xmath265 .",
    "complex symmetries fix pointwise a unique complex line in @xmath152 , called their _ mirror_.",
    "they preserve every complex line orthogonal to the mirror , acting on it as a half - turn .",
    "both types of involutions can be lifted to su(2,1 ) as follows .",
    "let @xmath1 be a point in @xmath266 .",
    "let @xmath179 be a lift of @xmath1 such that @xmath267 , with @xmath268 .",
    "if @xmath269 ( resp .",
    "@xmath215 ) , @xmath1 is a point of @xmath152 ( resp .",
    "is polar to a complex line in @xmath152 ) . consider the linear involution of @xmath21 defined by @xmath270 @xmath271 acts on @xmath152 as the central involution fixing the point @xmath272 when @xmath269 , and the complex symmetry across @xmath273 when @xmath274 .",
    "note that given an involution in pu(2,1 ) , its lift of the form is the unique lift which is also an involution .",
    "we will often identify a holomorphic involution with this lift .",
    "we will be interested in the space @xmath26 of conjugacy classes of the group @xmath275 ( see section  [ prelim ] for basic definitions ) . as a topological space ( with the quotient topology ) , this space is not hausdorff ; more specifically , the conjugacy class of complex reflections with a given ( nonzero ) rotation angle has the same neighborhoods as the screw - parabolic class with the same angle , and likewise , the identity and the 3 unipotent classes all share the same neighborhoods . for most of our purposes it will be sufficient to consider the set @xmath276 of _ regular semisimple _ classes , i.e. those classes of elements whose lifts are semisimple with distinct eigenvalues ( so , loxodromic or regular elliptic )",
    "however , it will also be useful to consider as in @xcite the maximal hausdorff quotient @xmath277 of the full space of conjugacy classes in @xmath278 .",
    "concretely , @xmath277 consists of the open dense set @xmath276 , together with the set @xmath279 of equivalence classes of complex reflections and screw - parabolics , as well as the identity and unipotents , which are identified in the quotient ; we will call such classes _ boundary classes_. we will denote by @xmath207 ( respectively @xmath209 , @xmath280 ) the subsets of @xmath26 consisting of loxodromic ( resp .",
    "elliptic , resp .",
    "regular elliptic ) elements of @xmath278 ; the conjugacy class of an element @xmath281 will be denoted @xmath282 $ ] .",
    "the global topology of @xmath26 can be described as follows : @xmath209 is closed ( in fact , compact ) , @xmath207 and @xmath283 are open and disjoint , and @xmath284 .",
    "note that @xmath207 and @xmath285 have natural smooth structures ( which were used in @xcite , @xcite and @xcite ) , whereas boundary classes are singular points of @xmath26 , as they have arbitrarily small neighborhoods homeomorphic to 3 half - disks glued along a common diameter ( 2 of them in @xmath209 , 1 in @xmath207 ) .",
    "as in the classical case of the poincar disk , the isometry type of an isometry is closely related to the trace of a lift to su(2,1 ) . the following proposition can be found in chapter 7 of @xcite ; see figure  [ deltoid ] .",
    "[ prop - deltoid]let @xmath286 denote the function defined for @xmath287 by : @xmath288 then , for any isometry @xmath289 with lift @xmath290 :    * @xmath242 is regular elliptic @xmath291 @xmath292 .",

    "* @xmath242 is unipotent or the identity @xmath291 @xmath296 .    combining the latter proposition with section [ section - loxo - classes ]",
    "gives the following :    [ rmk - real - loxo ] an element @xmath297 in su(2,1 ) represents a hyperbolic isometry if and only if @xmath298 , where @xmath299 and @xmath300 is a cube root of unity .",
    "an element @xmath297 in su(2,1 ) represents a half - turn loxodromic isometry if and only if @xmath301 , where @xmath302 and @xmath300 is a cube root of unity .",
    "there is one conjugacy class of antiholomorphic involutions in @xmath303 : _ real reflections _ , that fix pointwise an embedded copy @xmath304 .",
    "the standard example is the map @xmath305 in the unit ball of dimension @xmath1 .",
    "it is well known that any holomorphic isometry of @xmath120 is a product of two real reflections ( this is due to falbel and zocca @xcite in dimension two , and to choi @xcite in higher dimensions ) .",
    "in contrast , only very few elements of pu(2,1 ) are products of two holomorphic involutions .",
    "[ doubleproducts ] let @xmath306 be a holomorphic isometry of @xmath152 . then ,    1 .",
    "@xmath242 is a product of two central involutions if and only if it is hyperbolic .",
    "2 .   @xmath242 is a product of a complex symmetry and a central involution if and only if it is half - turn loxodromic or a complex symmetry .",
    "3 .   @xmath242 is a product of two complex symmetries if and only if it is hyperbolic , 3-step unipotent or real elliptic .    _",
    "proof_. let @xmath307 and @xmath308 be two involutions , lifted as in to the linear maps @xmath309 with @xmath310 and @xmath311 in @xmath312 . as in lemma",
    "[ position - droites ] , we denote by @xmath157 the projection to @xmath152 of @xmath156 when it is negative , and by @xmath158 its polar complex line if it is positive",
    ". then : @xmath313 let @xmath179 be a vector orthogonal to both @xmath153 and @xmath154 ; as the latter are linearly independant , by remark [ rem - asymptotic - lines ] , @xmath182 is a basis for @xmath189 except if @xmath153 and @xmath154 are both positive and represent asymptotic lines . assuming this is not the case , we can compute the trace of @xmath314 in this basis using .",
    "this gives : @xmath315 where @xmath316 was defined by .",
    "this expression remains valid when the two lines are asymptotic ( in which case the above triple of vectors is no longer a basis ) .",
    "hence the product of two involutions in su(2,1 ) always has real trace ( up to multiplication by a cube root of @xmath215 ) . from sections [ section - loxo - classes ] to [ section - ell - classes",
    "] , such a product can only be hyperbolic , half - turn loxodromic , unipotent , half - turn parabolic or real elliptic .",
    "there are three different cases , depending on the respective types of @xmath153 and @xmath154 .",
    "the results are obtained directly from lemma [ position - droites ] .    1 .",
    "if @xmath317 , then @xmath307 and @xmath308 are central involutions and @xmath316 can take any value in @xmath318 .",
    "we obtain all hyperbolic classes this way .",

    "@xmath316 can take any value in @xmath320 $ ] . for negative values of @xmath316",
    ", we obtain all possible half - turn loxodromic isometries . if @xmath166 , then @xmath167 belongs to the mirror of @xmath307 , and @xmath314",
    "is the complex symmetry about the line orthogonal to @xmath168 through @xmath167 .",
    "3 .   if @xmath321 then the cases where @xmath160 give all possible hyperbolic classes . in case @xmath322 ,",
    "the vector @xmath179 orthogonal to @xmath153 and @xmath154 has negative type , and is an eigenvector with eigenvalue @xmath215 of @xmath314 ( this follows directly from ) .",

    "@xmath61    from proposition [ doubleproducts ] , we see that generic holomorphic isometries are not products of two holomorphic involutions , in other words that @xmath20 has involution length at least 3 . in the next sections",
    ", we are going to determine which elements of pu(2,1 ) are products of three holomorphic involutions . to that end",
    ", we will use the following remarks .",
    "[ rem - specific - triple ] to any involution @xmath331 , we associate a sign : @xmath332 if it is a complex symmetry , or @xmath230 if it is a central involution ( this is the sign of @xmath333 for @xmath179 as in ) . to any triple of involutions @xmath13",
    "is thus associated a triple of signs @xmath334 .",
    "we will often shorten this notation by omitting the @xmath215 and only keeping the signs , e.g. @xmath335 will stand for @xmath336 .",
    "we will say that an isometry @xmath337 is a triple product of type @xmath334 if it is a product @xmath50 where @xmath46 has sign @xmath338 .    1 .",
    "fix a triple @xmath339 .",
    "if @xmath297 is a triple product of type @xmath334 , then it is also a triple product of type @xmath340 for any permutation @xmath341 . to verify this",
    ", is suffices to note that conjugating by @xmath307 amouts to applying the @xmath49-cycle @xmath342 and that two neighboring signs @xmath343 and @xmath344 can always be exchanged .",
    "for example if @xmath307 is a complex symmetry and @xmath308 a central involution , then @xmath345 is conjugate to @xmath308 and is thus a central involution , denoted @xmath346 .",
    "we then have @xmath347 and thus @xmath348 .",
    "thus it is enough to study the four triples @xmath349 , @xmath335 , @xmath350 and @xmath351 .",
    "2 .   proposition [ doubleproducts ] shows in particular that any product of two central involutions is also a product of two complex symmetries .",
    "this implies the following two facts . 1 .   to prove that an isometry @xmath352 pu(2,1 ) is a triple product of any type , its suffices to prove that it is a triple product of type @xmath350 and @xmath351 .",
    "in other words , it suffices to prove that @xmath297 is the product of an hyperbolic element and an involution of either type .",
    "if an isometry @xmath352 pu(2,1 ) can not be written as a @xmath349 triple product of type nor as a @xmath335 triple product , then it is not a product of three holomorphic involutions .",
    "to analyze products of three holomorphic involutions @xmath50 , we will view them as products of two isometries , one of which is a product of two involutions .",
    "as we have seen in section [ double ] , being a product of two holomorphic involutions gives restrictions on the conjugacy class .",
    "we are therefore led to study the following product map .",
    "we consider as in @xcite and @xcite the following question : given two conjugacy classes @xmath22 and @xmath23 in @xmath275 , what are the possible conjugacy classes for the product @xmath353 as @xmath297 varies in @xmath22 and @xmath354 varies in @xmath23 ? more specifically , given two semisimple conjugacy classes @xmath22 and @xmath23 , the problem is to determine the image of the map : @xmath355   \\end{array},\\ ] ] where @xmath26 is the set of conjugacy classes in pu(2,1 ) and @xmath27 $ ] denotes the conjugacy class of an element .",
    "when studying this question , _ reducible pairs _",
    "play a crucial role .",
    "we say that a subgroup @xmath356 is _ reducible _ if it fixes a point in @xmath188 ( so , either all elements of @xmath357 have a common fixed point in @xmath358 , or they all preserve a common complex line ) , and _",
    "irreducible _ otherwise .",
    "likewise we will say that a pair @xmath359 is reducible ( resp .",
    "irreducible ) if it generates a reducible ( resp .",
    "irreducible ) group .",
    "the strategy used in @xcite and @xcite consists of the following four parts :    1 .",
    "[ a ] prove that @xmath360 is closed ; 2 .",
    "[ b ] prove that images of irreducible pairs are interior points of @xmath360 ; 3 .",
    "[ c ] determine the set @xmath361 \\ , | \\ , ( a , b ) \\in { \\mathcal{c}}_1 \\times { \\mathcal{c}}_2 \\ , { \\rm reducible } \\}$ ] of _ reducible walls _ ; 4 .",
    "[ d ] determine which _ chambers _ , i.e. connected components of @xmath362 , are in the image - by parts [ a ] and [ b ] , @xmath360 is a union of chamber closures .",
    "parts [ a ] and [ b ] follow respectively from sections [ section - closed ] and [ section - open ] below . they imply the following crucial fact ( see section 2.5 of @xcite ) , which justifies part [ d ] .",
    "[ theo - full - or - empty ] any chamber of @xmath362 is either full or empty .",
    "note that parts [ a ] and [ b ] are obtained once and for all .",
    "in contrast , [ c ] and [ d ] require a case by case analysis .",
    "[ rem - red - ell ]    1 .   in the cases we consider we will observe that the intersection of the reducible walls with @xmath209 consists of a finite collection of linear segments that have slope @xmath230 , @xmath363 or @xmath364 .",
    "we refer to @xcite for a general proof of this fact .",
    "in particular , this shows that the diagonal segment @xmath365 can not contain any reducible walls .",
    "a useful consequence of theorem [ theo - full - or - empty ] is the following fact .",
    "let @xmath22 , @xmath23 and @xmath366 be three conjugacy classes , with @xmath367 semisimple .",
    "assume that there exist two pairs @xmath368 and @xmath369 such that @xmath370 for @xmath371 , with @xmath368 reducible and @xmath369 irreducible .",
    "as @xmath368 is reducible @xmath366 corresponds to a point on a reducible wall .",
    "as @xmath369 is irreducible , @xmath366 is interior to the image of the product map .",
    "this implies that all chambers having the point @xmath366 in their closure are full .",
    "we start with two general observations about reducible and irreducible pairs .",
    "recall that a _ special elliptic _ isometry in @xmath20 is one whose lifts have repeated eigenvalues ; geometrically this means that its angle pair has the form @xmath372 ( in which case it is a complex reflection about a line ) or @xmath373 ( in which case it is a complex reflection in a point ) .    [ reducibleproducts ] let @xmath374 . if @xmath297 and @xmath354 ( resp . @xmath297 and @xmath353 )",
    "are both special elliptic then the group @xmath375 is reducible .    _",
    "proof_. complex reflections about lines preserve all complex lines perpendicular to their mirror , and complex reflections about points preserve all complex lines containing their isolated fixed point . in all cases ,",
    "either @xmath297 and @xmath354 have a fixed point in common in @xmath358 or they preserve a common complex line .",
    "@xmath61    lemma [ reducibleproducts ] is very useful in determining which special elliptic elements are attained as products .",
    "it was used in the following form in the proof of proposition  4.1 of @xcite :    [ coro - diag ] if one of @xmath22 or @xmath23 is a conjugacy class of special elliptic elements , then any chamber of @xmath376 containing an open interval of the diagonal in its closure is empty .    _",
    "proof_. asssume we have such a chamber @xmath377 that is full . then if @xmath297 is special elliptic and the angle pair of @xmath353 lie on the diagonal , @xmath353 is special elliptic , and by lemma [ reducibleproducts ] the pair @xmath378 is reducible .",
    "as the pair @xmath378 generates the group @xmath379 , this implies that @xmath29 is also reducible .",
    "this means that the diagonal interval lying in the closure of @xmath377 is ( part of ) a reducible wall .",
    "this contradicts remark [ rem - red - ell ] . @xmath61",
    "the second observation is that any pair can be deformed to an irreducible pair , unless prohibited by lemma  [ reducibleproducts ] :    [ prop - open - dense ] let @xmath367 be 2 semisimple conjugacy classes in @xmath380 , at least one of which is regular semisimple .",
    "then irreducible pairs form an open dense subset of @xmath381 .    _",
    "proof_. recall that a pair @xmath359 is reducible if ( any lifts of ) @xmath382 have a common eigenvector in @xmath189 .",
    "therefore reducible pairs form a closed subset of @xmath383 , and irreducible pairs an open subset .    now",
    "if say @xmath22 is regular semisimple and @xmath23 semisimple ( and not the identity ) , then eigenspaces in @xmath189 of lifts to @xmath384 of elements of @xmath22 have ( complex ) dimension 1 , and likewise eigenspaces in @xmath189 of lifts to @xmath384 of elements of @xmath23 have ( complex ) dimension at most 2 .",
    "then , if @xmath385 is reducible , let @xmath386 be a common eigenvector of ( lifts of ) @xmath387 and @xmath388 ( resp .",
    "@xmath389 ) the eigenspace of @xmath390 ( resp .",
    "@xmath391 ) containing @xmath145 . then in a neighborhood of @xmath392 , any pair @xmath29 with @xmath393",
    "is irreducible , and since @xmath388 has dimension 1 and @xmath389 dimension at most 2 there exist such pairs arbitrarily close to @xmath392 .",
    "@xmath61    [ cor - at - least-1-full ] if @xmath367 are 2 semisimple conjugacy classes in @xmath394 , at least one of which is regular semisimple , then every reducible wall bounds at least one full chamber .    _",
    "proof_. by proposition [ prop - open - dense ] , any reducible pair , corresponding to a point on a reducible wall @xmath148 can be deformed into an irreducible pair .",
    "this either gives a point in one of the chambers bounding @xmath148 , which is therefore full , or a point on the reducible wall which is then also the image of an irreducible pair . as in remark",
    "[ rem - red - ell ] ( 2 ) , both chambers bounded by that wall are then full .",
    "@xmath61      let @xmath278 be the identity component of the isometry group of a riemannian symmetric space with negative sectional curvature . the _ translation length _ @xmath395 of an isometry @xmath396 is defined as @xmath397 .",
    "an isometry @xmath242 is called _ semisimple _ if the infimum is attained , i. e. if there exists @xmath398 such that @xmath399 . in the case of hyperbolic spaces ,",
    "semisimple isometries are the non - parabolic ones ( in other words , an isometry is semisimple if its matrix representatives are semisimple ) .",
    "theorem [ compactness ] below is the key point in this section .",
    "this compactness result , which as stated is proposition  2 of @xcite and is essentially theorem  3.9 of @xcite , is sometimes called the bestvina - paulin compactness theorem , .",
    "it is obtained by taking gromov - hausdorff limits to get an action on an @xmath38-tree .",
    "[ compactness ] let @xmath3 be a negatively curved riemannian symmetric space , @xmath400 , and @xmath401 , @xmath402 two sequences of semisimple elements of @xmath278 with uniformly bounded translation length",
    ". then either : + ( 1 ) there exists @xmath403 such that @xmath404 and @xmath405 converge in @xmath278 ( after passing to a subsequence ) , or + ( 2 ) the sequence of translation lengths @xmath406 is unbounded .",
    "we will use the following consequence of this result ( theorem  2 of @xcite ) .",
    "recall from the end of section  [ section - class - conj ] that we denote @xmath26 the space of conjugacy classes of @xmath278 , and @xmath277 the maximal hausdorff quotient of @xmath26 .",
    "[ theo - proper ] let @xmath22 and @xmath23 be two semisimple conjugacy classes in @xmath278 , and consider the diagonal action of @xmath278 on @xmath24 by conjugation .",
    "then : + ( a ) the product map @xmath407 descends to a map @xmath408 that is proper .",
    "+ ( b ) the image of @xmath409 is closed in @xmath277 .    _",
    "proof_. ( a ) if @xmath410 is a compact subset of @xmath277 and @xmath411 is ( a choice of representatives of ) a sequence in @xmath412 , the sequence of translation lengths @xmath406 is bounded , therefore by theorem  [ compactness ] @xmath412 is compact .",
    "+ ( b ) if @xmath413 is a sequence in @xmath414 converging to @xmath415 , let as above @xmath411 be a choice of representatives of preimages of @xmath416 .",
    "then the sequence of translation lengths @xmath406 is bounded , therefore by theorem  [ compactness ] ( after conjugating ) @xmath401 and @xmath402 converge in @xmath278 , say to @xmath242 , @xmath40 respectively . then by continuity of @xmath409",
    ", @xmath417 is in @xmath414 , which is therefore closed .",
    "@xmath61      [ irredsurject ]",
    "let @xmath367 be 2 semisimple conjugacy classes in @xmath275 , and @xmath29 be an irreducible pair in @xmath381 .",
    "then the differential of @xmath28 at @xmath29 is surjective and thus @xmath28 is locally surjective at that point .",
    "the key point in the proof is the following lemma ( see lemma 2.4 of @xcite , the proof of prop .",
    "4.2 of @xcite or the final section of @xcite in a different context ) . denoting @xmath418 the product map , and",
    "@xmath419 the lie algebra of the centralizer of the group generated by @xmath297 and @xmath354 :    [ imdmu ] the differential at a pair @xmath29 of the product map @xmath420 satisfies @xmath421 where the orthogonal is taken with respect to the killing form of @xmath278 .",
    "now if @xmath29 is irreducible , then @xmath422 , so @xmath420 is a submersion at such a point ( the killing form is non - degenerate ) .",
    "the proposition follows since the projection @xmath423 is open , as a quotient map .      in this section",
    "we review the case where the two classes @xmath22 and @xmath23 are elliptic as well as their product .",
    "this situation has been analyzed in detail in @xcite , but we recall it briefly for self - containedness .",
    "assume that the two classes correspond to angle pairs @xmath424 and @xmath425 with @xmath426 and @xmath427 . the possible reducible configurations for a pair @xmath29 in @xmath24 fall into three types , which correspond to points and segments in the affine chart @xmath428 ( see section [ section - ell - classes ] ) .    1 .",
    "* totally reducible pairs .",
    "* this is when @xmath297 and @xmath354 commute . in that case ,",
    "@xmath297 and @xmath354 have a common fixed point in @xmath152 and the same stable complex lines .",
    "the corresponding angle pairs are thus given by the two points @xmath429 and @xmath430 ( the precise order of the coordinates depends on the values of the @xmath431 ) .",
    "* spherical reducible pairs .",
    "* this is when @xmath297 and @xmath354 have a common fixed point in @xmath152 . in that case ,",
    "@xmath297 and @xmath354 can be lifted to u(2,1 ) as a pair @xmath432 + where @xmath433 and @xmath434 are matrices in u(2 ) with respective spectra @xmath435 and @xmath436 .",
    "the problem is thus reduced to the similar one in u(2 ) .",
    "the set of angle pairs of spherical reducible pairs is then the segment of slope @xmath230 connecting the two totally reducible vertices .",
    "this segment may appear as disconnected in @xmath428 ( see @xcite ) .",
    "* hyperbolic reducible pairs . *",
    "this is when @xmath297 and @xmath354 preserve a common complex line @xmath143 in @xmath152 . if @xmath297 and @xmath354 are regular , they each preserve two complex lines .",
    "when the product @xmath353 is elliptic , we will denote by @xmath437 its rotation angle in the line @xmath143 and by @xmath438 its rotation angle in the normal direction .",
    "there are four families of hyperbolic reducible configurations that correspond to the possible choices of rotation angles of @xmath297 and @xmath354 in the common stable complex line .",
    "the possible values of the angle pairs for hyperbolic reducible configurations are those lying on the projection to @xmath209 of one of the four segments @xmath439 in @xmath428 , where @xmath440 , @xmath441 , and @xmath439 is the affine segment defined by the conditions @xmath442 where we use the convention that @xmath443 and @xmath444 are disjoint .",
    "the wall @xmath439 corresponds to the case where @xmath297 and @xmath354 rotate through angles @xmath431 and @xmath445 respectively in the complex line @xmath143 .",
    "for example , the segment @xmath446 corresponds to the case when @xmath297 rotates through @xmath64 and @xmath354 through @xmath447 .",
    "then @xmath297 and @xmath354 can be conjugated in u(2,1 ) so that : @xmath448 where @xmath433 and @xmath434 are matrices in u(1,1 ) with respective spectra @xmath449 and @xmath450 .",
    "the eigenvalues of @xmath451 are @xmath452 ( positive type ) and @xmath453 ( negative type ) , for some @xmath325 and @xmath454 in @xmath455 .",
    "the angle pair of @xmath353 is given by @xmath456 on the other hand , the relation @xmath457 gives the relation @xmath458 .",
    "the precise range given in is obtained by applying proposition [ prop - invol - hyp - disc ] .",
    "in this section , we apply the strategy described in section [ section - strategy ] to prove that any loxodromic isometry is a product of three involutions of any kind .",
    "we start by giving a description of the reducible walls in the space @xmath207 of loxodromic classes , in angle - length coordinates @xmath459 ( see section  [ section - loxo - classes ] ) .",
    "[ loxred ] let @xmath367 be 2 semisimple conjugacy classes in @xmath275 .",
    "we denote by @xmath460 the corresponding set of reducible walls .    *",
    "if @xmath367 are both loxodromic ( or @xmath22 loxodromic and @xmath23 a complex reflection in a point ) , then @xmath461 consists of the single wall @xmath462 , where @xmath64 and @xmath65 are the rotation angles of @xmath22 and @xmath23 .",
    "* if @xmath22 is loxodromic and @xmath23 is regular elliptic ( or a complex reflection ) , let @xmath64 be the rotation angle of @xmath22 and @xmath463 the angle pair of @xmath23 .",
    "then @xmath461 consists of the two walls @xmath464 * if @xmath367 are both regular elliptic , then @xmath461 consists of three or four walls of the form @xmath465 , where @xmath325 ( resp .",
    "@xmath454 ) is one of the two rotation angles of @xmath22 ( resp .",
    "@xmath23 ) .    part ( a ) is actually contained in @xcite but we include a more detailed proof .",
    "note that if @xmath382 are both special elliptic then the group @xmath375 is always reducible by lemma  [ reducibleproducts ] .    _",
    "proof_. let @xmath466 be a reducible pair of semisimple isometries , with loxodromic product .",
    "in particular , @xmath297 and @xmath354 have a common eigenvector in @xmath189 . if @xmath297 and @xmath354 both admit @xmath467 as an eigenvector , with respective eigenvalues @xmath468 and @xmath469 , then the product @xmath353 has @xmath467 as an eigenvector with eigenvalue @xmath470 .",
    "as @xmath353 is loxodromic the value of @xmath470 determines the conjugacy class of @xmath353 if it has non unit modulus , and it determines the vertical line of @xmath207 to which @xmath471 $ ] belongs if it has unit modulus ( see section [ section - loxo - classes ] ) .",
    "the result will therefore depend on the respective type and number of eigenvectors of @xmath297 and @xmath354 .    1 .   if @xmath297 and @xmath354 are both loxodromic with attracting eigenvalues @xmath468 and @xmath469 then from the general form for loxodromics , their product has either @xmath472 as a positive type eigenvalue , or one of @xmath470 , @xmath473 @xmath474 and @xmath475 as a null type eigenvalue .",
    "all these complex numbers determine the same vertical line in @xmath207 .",
    "this gives the result when @xmath297 and @xmath354 are both loxodromic . if , say , @xmath354 is a complex reflection in a point , then @xmath297 and @xmath354 can only have a positive type common eigenvector .",
    "as all positive eigenvectors for @xmath354 have the same eigenvalue the same conclusion holds as for pairs of loxodromics .",
    "if @xmath297 is loxodromic and @xmath354 is regular elliptic or a complex reflection , then only a positive type vector can be a common eigenvector .",
    "if @xmath354 has angle pair @xmath463 , we see using and that the conjugacy class of @xmath353 belongs to one of the two vertical lines in @xmath207 given by .",
    "if @xmath297 and @xmath354 are both regular elliptic and @xmath353 is loxodromic , then again only a positive type vector can be a common eigenvector for @xmath297 and @xmath354 . as @xmath297 and @xmath354 each have two distinct ( unit modulus ) eigenvalues of positive type , this leaves three or four possibilities . indeed , denoting by @xmath476 and",
    "@xmath477 the respective ( pairs of ) arguments of the positive eigenvalues of @xmath297 and @xmath354 , the possible arguments of the positive type eigenvalue of @xmath353 belong to @xmath478 since @xmath297 and @xmath354 are regular elliptic , @xmath479 and @xmath480 so at least three of these four angles are distinct .    to finish proving proposition [ loxred",
    "] , we need to see that all points one the vertical lines described above are indeed attained by the product map .",
    "once the rotation angle @xmath174 of @xmath353 is fixed , the parameter @xmath481 ( in the notation of section [ section - loxo - classes ] ) describes the translation length of the corresponding loxodromic element .",
    "we now show that the cases where @xmath297 and @xmath354 preserve a common complex line suffice to cover the whole vertical line .",
    "indeed , in that case the translation length of @xmath353 is attained at any point of its axis , which is contained in the complex line preserved by @xmath297 and @xmath354 , a copy of the poincar disk .",
    "now if @xmath297 and @xmath354 have fixed conjugacy classes in psl(2,@xmath38 ) , their product @xmath353 can be hyperbolic with any translation length .",
    "this can either be seen as a simple exercice in plane hyperbolic geometry in the spirit of propositions [ prop - geod - sym - hyper ] and [ prop - invol - hyp - disc ] or as a consequence of theorem [ theo - proper ] , applied to the case where @xmath3 is the poincar disk .",
    "@xmath61    proposition [ loxred ] ( a ) shows that when @xmath22 and @xmath23 are loxodromic , the reducible walls do not disconnect @xmath207 . as shown by falbel and wentworth in @xcite , this implies the following proposition , which is theorem 1 of @xcite .",
    "[ theo - fw][3lox ] let @xmath22 , @xmath23 , @xmath366 be three loxodromic conjugacy classes in @xmath20 .",
    "then there exists @xmath482 such that @xmath483 .    _",
    "proof_. applying the first item of proposition [ loxred ] , we see that if @xmath466 is a reducible pair , the conjugacy class of @xmath353 can take any value in a fixed vertical line @xmath484 . as this vertical line",
    "does not disconnect @xmath207 , theorem  [ theo - full - or - empty ] and corollary  [ cor - at - least-1-full ] imply that @xmath360 contains @xmath207 .",
    "@xmath61    [ rem - fw2 ] the first item of proposition [ loxred ] implies that the conclusion of proposition [ 3lox ] still holds if one of the three conjugacy classes is a complex reflection about a point .",
    "however , if at least two of @xmath297 , @xmath354 and @xmath377 are complex reflections about points , then the group they generate is reducible , by lemma [ reducibleproducts ] .",
    "[ prop - loxo - any - triple ] any loxodromic element in pu(2,1 ) is a product of three holomorphic involutions of any kind .",
    "we now prove proposition [ prop - loxo - any - triple ] using the ideas of section [ section - product - map ] . in section [ section - parab - triple ] we will give an alternate proof which provides explicit configurations of involutions .    _",
    "proof_. by remark [ rem - specific - triple ] , we only need to prove that a loxodromic isometry is a triple product of types @xmath351 and @xmath350 . by proposition [ doubleproducts ]",
    "it suffices to show that any loxodromic map can written both    1 .   as a product of a hyperbolic map and a central involution , and 2 .   as a product of a hyperbolic map and a complex symmetry .    to prove the first item , it suffices to apply proposition [ theo - fw ] and remark [ rem - fw2 ] in the case where @xmath297 is hyperbolic and @xmath354 is a central involution .",
    "we see that @xmath353 can belong to any loxodromic class .    for the second item , in the notation of proposition [ loxred ] ,",
    "we have @xmath485 , @xmath486 and @xmath487 . the two reducible walls are thus @xmath488 and @xmath489 .",
    "to prove the result , we apply the strategy suggested by the second item of remark [ rem - red - ell ] , namely we show that any half - turn loxodromic ( that is with rotation angle @xmath225 ) can also be obtained as a product @xmath490 , where @xmath40 is hyperbolic , @xmath331 a complex symmetry , and the pair @xmath491 is irreducible .",
    "consider the real plane @xmath492 , and @xmath40 a hyperbolic map preserving @xmath493 ( that is , a hyperbolic element of @xmath494 ) .",
    "consider a geodesic @xmath90 in @xmath493 , with endpoints distinct from those of the axis of @xmath40 , and @xmath143 the complex line containing it .",
    "the complex reflection @xmath331 about @xmath143 preserves @xmath493 and acts on it as the reflection about the geodesic @xmath90 .",
    "the product @xmath490 preserves @xmath493 and",
    "@xmath495 is the product of a hyperbolic map and a reflection , thus either a glide reflection or a reflection .",
    "this means that @xmath490 is either a complex symmetry or a half - turn loxodromic .",
    "applying proposition [ prop - geod - sym - hyper ] , we see that @xmath490 can have any translation length , thus lie in any half - turn loxodromic conjugacy class .",
    "now , the pair @xmath491 is irreducible because @xmath40 and @xmath331 have no common fixed point in @xmath188 .",
    "this proves that the two chambers bounded by @xmath496 are full .",
    "hence , @xmath497 is onto @xmath207 in that case . @xmath61",
    "our goal in this section is to show that not all elliptic isometries are triple products of involutions , and to determine precisely which regular elliptic conjugacy classes can not be written as triple products of involutions . by remark [ rem - specific - triple ] , it suffices to determine those classes that can be written neither as a product of type @xmath335 nor of type @xmath349 .",
    "to do so , we will study the products of an involution of any type with the product of two complex symmetries . by proposition [ doubleproducts ] , this means we have to study pairs @xmath498 where @xmath331 is an involution of any type and @xmath297 is either hyperbolic , 2-step unipotent or real elliptic ( see section [ section - ell - classes ] for definition ) .",
    "as hyperbolic and real elliptic isometries are semisimple we will apply the strategy described in section [ section - product - map ] to determine those elliptic classes that can be written as such products .",
    "we will see that these classes correspond to angle pairs lying in a union of polygons in the triangle @xmath428 .",
    "now , 2-step unipotent isometries can be seen both as limits of sequences of hyperbolic isometries and of sequences of real elliptics .",
    "this can be seen by considering a sequence of pairs of complex lines @xmath499 with respective complex symmetries @xmath271 and @xmath500 . if @xmath501 and @xmath502 are ultraparallel ( resp . intersecting ) for all @xmath1 and converge to a pair @xmath503 of asymptotic lines , then the product @xmath504 is hyperbolic ( resp .",
    "real elliptic ) and @xmath505 is 2-step unipotent . as",
    "a consequence the elliptic classes that are products of one involution and a 2-step unipotent isometry lie in the closure of the set of classes that can be written as products of one involution and a hyperbolic or real elliptic isometry .",
    "for that reason we will only consider pairs @xmath498 where @xmath331 is an involution and @xmath297 is hyperbolic or real elliptic .",
    "the result is the following .",
    "[ prop - ell - triple ] ( 1 ) an elliptic isometry is the product of one central involution and two complex symmetries if and only if its angle pair lies in the shaded region @xmath506 depicted on figure [ 1-central - invols-2-crefl - ell ] .",
    "+ ( 2 ) an elliptic isometry is the product of three complex symmetries if and only if its angle pair lies in the shaded region @xmath507 depicted on figure [ 3-crefl - ell ] .",
    "+    from proposition [ prop - ell - triple ] , we obtain the following by applying remark [ rem - specific - triple ] .    [ coro - ell - triple ] an elliptic isometry @xmath508 is a product of three involutions if and only if its angle pair lies outside the two open triangles @xmath48 and @xmath509 given by their vertices as follows .",
    "@xmath510    the two triangles @xmath48 and @xmath509 are pictured on figure [ 3-invols - ell ] .    to prove proposition [ prop - ell - triple ]",
    "we will separate the cases , first studying products of an involution an a hyperbolic isometry , then products of an involution and a real elliptic isometry .      applying the strategy of section [ section - product - map ] we first need to describe the reducible walls .",
    "we consider pairs @xmath511 where @xmath307 is an involution and @xmath297 is hyperbolic .",
    "there are two cases .",
    "* first assume @xmath307 is a complex symmetry . if @xmath512 is regular elliptic it has no boundary fixed point and thus the only possible common fixed point in @xmath188 for @xmath307 and @xmath297 is the point polar to the complex axis of @xmath297 .",
    "this implies that the axis of @xmath297 and the mirror of @xmath307 are either equal or orthogonal . in the first case ,",
    "@xmath512 is loxodromic , as @xmath307 fixes pointwise the axis of @xmath297 .",
    "therefore , the mirror of @xmath307 must be orthogonal to the complex axis of @xmath297 . in particular @xmath307 acts on the complex axis of @xmath297 as a half - turn .",
    "* if @xmath307 is a central involution , its eigenvectors are either of positive or negative type ( but not of null type ) , and so reducibility means that the fixed point of @xmath307 belongs to the complex axis of @xmath297 ( which is thus perserved by @xmath307 ) .    in both cases , we see that @xmath307 preserves the complex axis of @xmath297 and acts on it by a half - turn .",
    "we use the ball model of @xmath152 , with hermitian form @xmath513 .",
    "we can normalize so that lifts of @xmath307 , @xmath297 and @xmath512 to su(2,1 ) have the form @xmath514 in , @xmath307 is a central involution when @xmath269 and a complex symmetry when @xmath274 .",
    "as @xmath297 is hyperbolic , the @xmath515 matrix @xmath433 has spectrum @xmath516 for some @xmath217 .",
    "similarly @xmath512 is elliptic and thus @xmath434 has eigenvalues @xmath452 ( of positive type ) and @xmath453 ( of negative type ) for some @xmath517 .",
    "the determinant of @xmath512 is equal to @xmath215 , and therefore we have @xmath518 $ ] , that is @xmath519 or @xmath520 .",
    "the angle pair of @xmath512 is given by @xmath521 where @xmath437 is the rotation angle of @xmath512 in the complex axis of @xmath297 ( the common preserved complex line ) , and @xmath438 is the rotation angle in the normal direction . using the conditions on the sum @xmath522",
    ", we see that the angle pair @xmath523 of @xmath512 satisfies one of the following two relations @xmath524 we denote by @xmath525 and @xmath526 the segments given by and for @xmath527 ( see figure [ 2segments ] ) .",
    "[ prop-2segments ] let @xmath297 be a hyperbolic isometry with fixed conjugacy class .",
    "+ ( 1 ) if @xmath307 is a central involution such that @xmath511 is reducible , then the possible angle pairs for the product @xmath512 when it is elliptic are the points of @xmath525 ( see figure [ 2segments ] ) .",
    "+ ( 2 ) if @xmath307 is a complex symmetry such that @xmath511 is reducible , then the possible angle pairs for the product @xmath512 when it is elliptic are the points of @xmath526 ( see figure [ 2segments ] ) .    _",
    "proof_. we know already that in both cases , the restriction of @xmath307 to the axis of @xmath297 is a half - turn . as a consequence , we can apply proposition [ prop - invol - hyp - disc ] to the restrictions of @xmath307 and @xmath297 .    1 .",
    "if @xmath307 is a central involution , decompose @xmath297 as a product @xmath528 of two central involutions with fixed points on the ( real ) axis of @xmath297 .",
    "clearly , if @xmath307 coincides with @xmath308 or @xmath529 , the product @xmath512 is a central involution , and in this case @xmath530 .",
    "this point is the midpoint of @xmath525 .",
    "deforming this configuration , proposition [ prop - invol - hyp - disc ] shows that any point on @xmath525 can be obtained by a reducible product of three central involutions .",
    "if @xmath307 is a complex symmetry , we decompose @xmath297 as a product @xmath528 of two complex symmetries and obtain in the case where @xmath531 or @xmath532 that @xmath512 is also a complex symmetry . in this case @xmath533 and @xmath534 , which gives the midpoint of @xmath526 . by a similar argument any point on with @xmath527",
    "can be obtained by a reducible product of three complex symmetries .",
    "now consider three central involutions @xmath13 with fixed points in a common complex line @xmath143 .",
    "the triple product @xmath50 acts on @xmath143 as a half - turn if and only if at least two of the @xmath46 s are equal . in that case",
    ", @xmath50 is a central involution.this proves in particular that a complex symmetry can not be a product @xmath512 where the the pair @xmath511 is reducible , @xmath307 is a central involution and @xmath297 is hyperbolic .    by a similar argument , a central involution can not be a product @xmath512 where @xmath511 is reducible , @xmath307 is a complex reflection of order two and @xmath297 is hyperbolic .",
    "if a point of @xmath525 were a reducible product of a complex symmetry and a hyperbolic , then by proposition [ prop - invol - hyp - disc ] , we could deform it continuously to obtain the midpoint of @xmath525 .",
    "this contradicts the previous discussion .",
    "a similar argument shows that no point of @xmath535 can be a reducible product of a central involution and a hyperbolic map .",
    "@xmath61    the following corollary describes the reducible walls .",
    "it is obtained in a straightforward way from proposition [ prop-2segments ] by projecting the two segments @xmath525 and @xmath526 onto the lower half of the square by reduction modulo @xmath536 and symmetry about the diagonal .",
    "[ red - wall-1 ] let @xmath22 be a conjugacy class of involutions , @xmath23 be a hyperbolic conjugacy class , and @xmath537 be a reducible pair such that @xmath512 is elliptic .    1 .",
    "if @xmath22 is the class of central involutions , then the angle pair of @xmath512 can take any value on the two segments @xmath538 $ ] and @xmath539 $ ] .",
    "if @xmath22 is the class of complex symmetries , then the angle pair of @xmath512 can take any value on the two segments @xmath540 $ ] and @xmath541 $ ] .",
    "these segments are the thicker ones on figures [ central - hyper ] and [ crefl - hyper ] .",
    "we can now describe all elliptic classes that are obtained as a product of an involution and a hyperbolic map .",
    "[ prop - image - invol - hyper ] ( 1 ) an elliptic isometry is the product of a central involution and a hyperbolic isometry if and only if its angle pair lies in the dashed polygon depicted on figure [ central - hyper ] .",
    "+ ( 2 ) an elliptic isometry is the product of a complex symmetry and a hyperbolic isometry if and only if its angle pair lies in the dashed polygon depicted on figure [ crefl - hyper ] .    _",
    "proof_. for each of the reducible walls , corollary  [ cor - at - least-1-full ] tells us that at least one of the chambers bounded by this wall is full . in the case where @xmath307 is a central involution ,",
    "corollary  [ coro - diag ] tells us that the two chambers bounded by a piece of the diagonal are empty ( see figure [ central - hyper ] ) . therefore the third chamber must be full . in the case where @xmath307 is a complex symmetry , corollary [ coro - diag ]",
    "tells us that the chamber bounded by the diagonal is empty .",
    "applying corollary [ cor - at - least-1-full ] at the intersection point of the reducible walls tells us that the three other chambers are full .",
    "@xmath61      central involution has angle pair @xmath263 ; for such pairs the reducible walls are as follows .",
    "[ prop - central - real - ell ] let @xmath511 be a reducible pair , where @xmath307 is a central involution and @xmath297 is real elliptic with angle pair @xmath257 for some fixed @xmath258 $ ] .",
    "the possible angle pairs for the product @xmath512 ( when it is elliptic ) are the two segments @xmath542 $ ] and @xmath543 $ ] .",
    "these two segments are depicted on figure [ central - real - ell ] .    _",
    "proof_. we are now dealing with the product map on the product of two elliptic conjugacy classes .",
    "the general situation in that case has been described in section [ section - red - ell - ell ] . in the case",
    "we are interested in the angle pair of @xmath307 is @xmath544 . in particular ,",
    "the two totally reducible points are equal and the spherical reducible wall is reduced to the point @xmath545 .",
    "similarly , there are only two hyperbolic reducible segments , which , in the notation of section [ section - red - ell - ell ] are @xmath546 and @xmath446 , with @xmath547 from the precise description of @xmath546 and @xmath446 given by , we see that these segments are those emanating from the point @xmath545 with slope @xmath363 and @xmath364 , and connecting it respectively to the horizontal and vertical edges of the square ( see figure [ central - real - ell ] ) . @xmath61    we can now describe the intersection of the product map with @xmath209 in this case . it is given in the following corollary , which is straightforward from proposition [ prop - central - real - ell ] by applying the results of section [ section - product - map ] ( in particular , theorem [ theo - full - or - empty ] , corollary [ coro - diag ] and corollary [ cor - at - least-1-full ] ) .",
    "[ coro - image - central - real - ell ] the possible angle pairs for the product of a central involution and a real elliptic map with angle pair @xmath257 are those points in the ( convex ) polygon with vertices @xmath548 , @xmath549 , @xmath550 and @xmath551 .",
    "the following proposition is straightforward by taking the union of all polygons described in corollary [ coro - image - central - real - ell ] when @xmath174 varies from @xmath105 to @xmath55 .",
    "an elliptic element is the product of a central involution and two complex symmetries with intersecting mirrors if and only if its angle pairs belongs to the convex polygon with vertices @xmath552 , @xmath544 , @xmath553 and @xmath551 .",
    "observe that this polygon is the same as the one for the product of a central involution and a hyperbolic map .",
    "we now have a complex symmetry , with angle pair @xmath265 , and we fix a real elliptic conjugacy class .",
    "reducible walls are again otained by applying the results described in section [ section - red - ell - ell ] with , this time    @xmath554    [ prop - crefl - real - ell ] let @xmath555 be a reducible pair , where @xmath556 is a complex symmetry and @xmath297 is a real elliptic with angle pair @xmath257 for some fixed @xmath258 $ ] .",
