    "\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    the aspect of the segment @xmath562 in the chart @xmath428 is made more explicit in the table given by figure [ table - s3 ] .",
    "the wall @xmath563 is obtained from @xmath562 by the symmetry about the anti - diagonal of the square @xmath220 ^ 2 $ ] , given by @xmath567 .",
    "this symmetry corresponds to conjugating the pair @xmath555 by an anti - holomorphic map , which preserves both conjugacy classes of @xmath556 and @xmath297 ans is therefore an expected symmetry of the set of possible angle pairs .",
    "the reducible segments are depicted for various values of @xmath174 on figures [ crefl - reali ] to [ crefl - realiv ] .",
    "the two totally reducible vertices lie respectively on the lines with equations @xmath568 and @xmath569 . for all values of @xmath174 ,",
    "the spherical reducible segment appears disconnected in the affine chart of @xmath209 and is contained in the union of the latter lines .",

    "we now prove theorem [ main ] , stated in the introduction : the involution length of @xmath20 is 4 .",
    "proof_. [ proof of theorem [ main ] ] it only remains to prove that those elements in pu(2,1 ) that are not products of two or three central involutions , are products of four central involutions .",
    "this leaves :    1 .",
    "the regular elliptics whose angle pair does not lie in the shaded polygon of figure [ central - hyper ] .",
    "non - regular elliptic isometries ( complex reflections about lines and about points with arbitrary rotation angles ) .",
    "2-step unipotent parabolic isometries .    for the first part",
    ", it suffices to prove that any regular elliptic map is a product of two hyperbolic isometries .",
    "to do so , we fix two hyperbolic conjugacy classes @xmath22 and @xmath23 and apply the strategy of section [ section - product - map ] .",
    "if @xmath29 is a reducible pair in @xmath24 with elliptic product , then only a positive type vector can be a common eigenvector for @xmath297 and @xmath354 .",
    "in particular , the product @xmath353 has a lift to su(2,1 ) of the form @xmath581 where @xmath451 has eigenvalues @xmath582 , where @xmath452 has positive type , @xmath453 has negative type and @xmath325 , @xmath454 lie in @xmath455 .",
    "the rotation angles of @xmath353 are @xmath437 ( in the complex line preserved by @xmath297 and @xmath354 ) and @xmath438 ( in the normal direction ) .",
    "applying the same arguments as in sections [ section - triple - loxo ] and [ section - reg - ell - product ] we see that the two rotation angles of @xmath353 satisfy @xmath583 this implies by projecting to the lower triangle of the square @xmath220 ^ 2 $ ] that the reducible walls are the two segments given by @xmath584\\mbox { and } r_2 = \\bigl[(\\pi,0),(2\\pi,2\\pi)\\bigr]\\ ] ] considering configurations of two hyperbolic isometries preserving a common real plane , we see that all angle pairs @xmath585 are obtained by irreducible configurations ( these pairs form the dashed segment on figure [ hip - hip - ell ] ) .",
    "this implies that all regular elliptic isometries are products of four central involutions .",
    "lets us now consider non regular elliptics .",
    "first , complex reflections about points have angle pairs of the form @xmath586 lying on the diagonal of figure [ hip - hip - ell ] . as the image of the product map",
    "is closed , they are obtained as limits of regular elliptic products of two hyperbolic maps . secondly , we know from proposition [ prop - ell - triple ] that for every regular elliptic element @xmath587 with angle pair @xmath588 , there exists a triple of involutions @xmath13 such that @xmath589 ( note the pair @xmath588 lies in @xmath590 on figure [ central - hyper ] ) .",
    "now , consider the central involution @xmath591 about the fixed point of @xmath587 .",
    "the product @xmath592 has angle pair @xmath593 .",
    "this shows that @xmath592 is a complex reflection , and that any complex reflection can be obtained this way .",
    "finally , we consider 2-step parabolics .",
    "we know from sections [ section - screw ] and [ section - last - cases ] that any half - turn parabolic @xmath493 is a product of three involutions .",
    "writing @xmath594 , call @xmath591 the complex symmetry about the complex line preserved by @xmath493 .",
    "then the product @xmath592 is 2-step parabolic ; for example when @xmath595 we obtain @xmath596}$ ] . @xmath61          [ 2lox1ell ]",
    "let @xmath366 be a regular elliptic conjugacy class in @xmath20 .",
    "there exists an open subset of @xmath598 , containing @xmath599 ( and depending explicitly on @xmath366 ) such that for any @xmath367 in this subset , there exists @xmath597 such that @xmath483",
    ".    we can now prove theorem [ invollengthn ] , stated in the introduction : the involution length of pu(@xmath1,1 ) is at most 8 for all @xmath0 . the proof is done by combining the ingredients of theorem  [ main ] and theorem 3.1 of @xcite .    _",
    "proof_. [ proof of theorem [ invollengthn ] ] let @xmath352 pu(@xmath1,1 ) be a holomorphic isometry of @xmath120 .",
    "first assume that @xmath297 is elliptic , i.e. belongs to a copy of u(@xmath1 ) ( identified to @xmath600 , for example via the embedding @xmath601 ) .",
    "given any element @xmath602 with @xmath603 , we extend @xmath434 to an element @xmath354 of u(@xmath1,1 ) as follows : @xmath604 then @xmath353 belongs to @xmath605 , so by theorem 3.1 and lemma 3.3 of @xcite it is a product of at most four involutions of @xmath606 .",
    "the matrix @xmath354 corresponds to an elliptic isometry preserving a copy of @xmath152 in @xmath120 .",
    "its rotation angles are @xmath607 , where @xmath64 and @xmath65 are the rotation angles of @xmath608 .",
    "the only constraint on @xmath64 and @xmath65 is that @xmath609 .",
    "but every line of the form @xmath610 intersects the region @xmath611 representing elliptic conjugacy classes which are triple products of involutions ( see figure 11 and proposition [ prop - ell - triple ] ) .",
    "therefore we can choose @xmath612 in such a way that @xmath608 , resp .",
    "@xmath354 , is a product of three involutions in pu(2,1 ) , resp . in pu(@xmath1,1 ) ( again , under the embedding of @xmath613 as @xmath614 ) .",
    "therefore @xmath353 is a product of at most 7 involutions .",
    "now if @xmath297 is not elliptic , there exists an involution @xmath615 pu(@xmath1,1 ) such that @xmath616 is elliptic .",
    "indeed , pick any point @xmath617 , so that @xmath618 , and let @xmath331 be the central involution about the midpoint of @xmath619",
    ". then @xmath616 fixes @xmath620 , therefore @xmath616 is a product of at most 7 involutions and @xmath297 is a product of at most 8 involutions .",
    "@xmath61                _ proof_. it suffices to show that every element in pu(2,1 ) has a square root which is a product of three involutions .",
    "indeed , if @xmath307 , @xmath308 and @xmath529 are involutions , then we have @xmath625 $ ] . +",
    "( 1 ) this is clear for loxodromic isometries , as the square root of a loxodromic map is loxodromic and thus is a product of three complex symmetries .",
    "+ ( 2 ) every screw- or 2-step unipotent parabolic isometry has a square root which is screw parabolic , thus a product of thee complex symmetries . the square root of a 3-step unipotent isometry is also 3-step unipotent , and thus a product of three complex symmetries .",
    "+ ( 3 ) let @xmath587 be an elliptic element with angle pair @xmath251 .",
    "its square roots are those elliptic elements with angle pairs @xmath626 , where @xmath192 and @xmath1 are @xmath105 or @xmath215 .",
    "this implies in particular that every elliptic element has a square root which is regular elliptic with angle pair in @xmath627 ( see figures [ central - hyper ] and [ crefl - hyper ] ) , and hence is a triple product of involutions . @xmath61"
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we study decompositions of complex hyperbolic isometries as products of involutions . </S>",
    "<S> we show that pu(2,1 ) has involution length 4 and commutator length 1 , and that for all @xmath0 pu(@xmath1,1 ) has involution length at most 8 . </S>"
  ]
}
